ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn a lot more about egypt which I knew nothing about and learn about studying ancient civ which is cool!
A skill developed was learning about the archaeology of a site and applying that to a new site. For example, seeing how one site was laid out helps you understand a new site.
ancient egyptian history

I learned a lot about how historians use archeological evidence to challenge the bias of textual evidence. I have never taken a history course focused on archeology, and I really enjoyed learning about the archeological history of ancient Egypt and how we use archeology evidence to reconstruct history.
We studied ancient Egypt in depth, specifically each of the 3 Kingdoms and pharaohs that ruled during those times.
General survey of ancient Egyptian history from the predynastic to the Roman period.

This course focused heavily on the archaeological remains of ancient Egypt and the historical evidence these remnants provide. It touched on many major aspects of ancient Egyptian history including religion, burial, and monumental architecture. It also improved my skills on reading primary sources and ancient Egyptian literature and using it as evidence when developing an argument.
egyptian history and literature
I learned a bunch of interesting things about ancient Egypt and its artifacts.
Course provided me with basic overview of history of Ancient Egypt.

If you have been wanting to learn about Ancient Egypt, this is the course for you. You learn everything from the pre-dynastic (basically cave men) days all the way up until the Romans took over. It is fascinating and fun.

Overview of ancient Egyptian life, culture, and history

Overall easy history course that has interesting content but not very engaging lectures
I learnt a lot about the History of Egypt and its relations with foreign countries. Each era of Ancient Egypt was looked at closely and gave a great summary of its development.
Awesome
I learned all about Ancient Egypt
I learned about the history of Egypt.
Egypt
knowledge on ancient Egyptian history regarding the dynasties civilizations and pharaohs
I learned how to analyze history papers and about the underdiscussed value of Egyptian culture and history.
I learned about ancient egypt.
I learned about the development and history of Egyptian civilization, as well as skills for managing a large lecture-style class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Only improvement would be the organization.
It is very well organized.
professors care about making lecture engaging
organized

My only complaint is that some of my classmates didn't seem to take this class seriously, so they were never prepared for section. As a result, only a couple people (in a section of 20+ students) would actually participate in section, and it just felt a little awkward. It seemed like most people didn't do the reading, but that prevented us from having engaging conversations during section.

Very dense information during lectures at times and I wish the material was taught in a more organized way to depict a timeline. The first half of the class lectures felt disorganized and were oftentimes confusing in regards to time periods.
Great professors and guest lecturers! Sometimes the readings can be a little specific and boring tbh but it's good that there usually isn't much assigned.

I thought the incorporation of ancient Egyptian literature into the course was fascinating. Professors Moeller and Manning infused the course with a lot of passion for ancient Egyptian history, which was enjoyable to be a part of. I did have difficulty with the organization of the course. I wish lectures focused more on teaching the narrative of lecture topics and instead focused very heavily on archaeological remains. I often found that I left lecture not knowing very much about the time periods the lectures were meant to cover since we talked more about interpreting remains versus tracking the continuities, changes, and events of the history. The main readings also focused very heavily on the archaeology of ancient Egypt although each chapter began with helpful sections detailing the historical narrative, which was helpful. I typically like to cover the bulk of the content in lecture, using readings and section to supplement the lecture, but in the course (largely in an effort to punish the students who did not attend lecture), the bulk of the content came from the readings with lecture and seminar feeling slightly scrambled with supplementary analysis. I'm very grateful for the robust study guide provided for the final exam because otherwise I would not have known what information to focus on.
The material was very interesting but sometimes the structure of the lectures was confusing and hard to follow.

The professors are both brilliant and the lectures were mostly fascinating. (The teaching fellow Mike's lecture on Deir El Medina was particularly memorable!) The material itself is fantastic. Anyone who cares about human life and civilization should study Egypt.

The main issue with the course is the simple reality that most of the students in the lecture hall don't seem to care about Egypt; why they are in the course, I don't understand. Because the professor were clearly disappointed in the lack of participation, they often asked for volunteers from the classroom to answer questions during lecture. Unfortunately, clearly only a handful of students ever did the reading, so basically only three students ever spoke. 

One specific note is that the lectures sometimes became so full of archeological specifics that they lost sight of what we are trying to cover during the class.

Strengths are that the material was interesting and engaging. The content was easy to take notes on and easy to understand if you went to class and listened. The Instructors were phenomenal and very understanding and just wanted us to share love and learn. Weaknesses were maybe that it wasn't recorded so if you were sick, you missed out on a lot.
Strengths are that the lectures and discussion sections were very informative. Weaknesses were that the readings felt slightly unorganized.

Strengths:  cool subject matter.  Great Professors and TAs.  Guest lectures

Weaknesses: low attendance by students so professors made the final very hard

Strengths: info taught 
Weakness: the prompts for essays were a little confusing sometimes
Strength section, weakness class slides
lecture could be more engaging

The class was not very engaging. The lectures did not focus well on information that ended up on the final. I wish the lectures were more of relaying information. They tried to make it more discussion style but very little information got taught during those and we have separate discussion sections so there was no need for that.
I thought the professors were great and I liked the materials we used; I do feel the class may have been a bit too broad in its goals or we just needed more time in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you need an easy class that is still interesting and on a cool subject matter!
Yes
yes
yes
Yes, but they need to be interested in history to enjoy the class.
It's not super interesting but it's a good gut if you're looking for a HU credit.

I would hope to recommend this course to another student, but I would want several structural changes before making a recommendation. Professors Moeller and Manning are fantastic and very passionate about the course content. The content itself is rich and fascinating. However, I thought the structure of the course made it difficult reach the fascinating content. I would want lectures to focus more on the changes, continuities, and events of ancient Egyptian history with archaeological remains used as supplementary content (instead lectures focused primarily on the remains, making it harder to piece together the narrative).
Id recommend this to anyone who needs a Hu or wants a super interesting class with light workload and fun material.
yes
Absolutely!

If you actually care about Egypt you probably should just take a different course. Sadly, most of the students who take this class are athletes who are just taking this as a gut credit. 

I know it sounds dramatic, but this course truly made me question what Yale stands for as an institution. Why does Yale admit so many students who genuinely seem uninterested in learning? Or are made so busy through sports that they can not make time to learn? Alas. Mostly, I feel sorry for the two professors who are both brilliant people and good teachers.
Absolutely! Just go to class. Instructors are great, TAs are great, the material is amazing. The facts and cool things you learn are awesome.

Take it if you're interested in ancient Egypt and/or don't want to work hard

Content is interesting but lectures are disorganized
Definitely recommend for a Humanities credit.
Yes!  If theyre looking for a nice Hu credit, its a great course that isnt too hard but you still learn a lot. Egypt is super cool!
Yes - this was a fun course.
Yes
yes, it was well taught and the assignments were clear
Definitely- I do not prefer to take Humanities, but found this class to really help me improve my writing skills.
If you need a humanities credit, yes I would recommend it.
Yes, if this is an area you're interested in. The class is informative without being too challenging.
